Award.AwardTitle: Exploring Public Engagement with Real-time Experimentation in Different Public Venues

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
A team from Michigan State University, in partnership with six science, art-science, and art museum venues around the country and with the assistance of researchers at Georgia Institute of Technology, is implementing an EAGER project to conduct ongoing experiments on the chemical precursors to life as exhibit experiences for visitors to these venues. The experiments, to be run over the course of several months as the exhibit travels around the country, expand on the 1950s' work of Stanley Miller and Harold Urey, which continues to stimulate new investigations and publications, including experiments being conducted on the International Space Station.

The experiments/exhibits share key features across the three different kinds of venues, allowing the team to study and compare the impacts on the various publics of engaging them in real-time science experiments. Two major goals are (1) to explore new ways to attract public interest in science by performing in public settings previously untried experiments on the chemical precursors to life, and (2) to investigate how the context of different kinds of venues and their visitor characteristics affect how visitors interpret the experience and what they learn. The team is also exploring how various data visualization representations can be designed to foster public interest and understanding. The intent is to develop an approach that has potential applications to other STEM content domains and expanding the reach to broader public audiences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project had three goals:

GOAL 1) To explore new ways to attract public interest in science by performing previously untried experiments, in real-time, in public settings.

GOAL 2) To explore more specifically whether presenting science in an art venues attracts people who would otherwise not seek out informal science education experiences. 

GOAL 3) To explore the problems associated with data transformation as a means to communicate experimental results to both scientific and non-scientific (especially artistic) audiences.

MEANS: Achieving our goals required us to create an experimental device capable of performing a wide range of novel experiments that could function as a scientific apparatus in a science museum and also as an art piece when exhibited in an art venue. Our solution was to re-create a famous 1953 experiment by Stanley Miller by transforming it into a “sculpture and performance piece” and running novel experiments with it. Part of this “performance” involved training staff or volunteers at each venue to take daily samples and do simple experiments that would enlighten visitors as to the scientific processes taking place both inside the apparatus and between the apparatus and the scientist. Data from these sampling procedures, as well as the samples themselves, were to be sent regularly (daily or weekly) to the project investigators for transformation into visual images of high aesthetic value to communicate with non-scientific audiences such as artists.

VENUES: We exhibited at five venues. Two of these were science centers: The Michigan State University Museum (East Lansing, MI); and the Reuben Fleet Science Center (San Diego, CA). The remaining sites were arts venues: The Beall Center for Art and Technology at the University of California, Irvine (Irvine, CA); the Williamson Gallery of the Art Center College of Design (Pasadena, CA); and Zero1, an art gallery in Palo Alto, CA.

GOAL 1 OUTCOMES: Our first goal was to determine whether performing live experimentation in public spaces was an effective means to attract public interest in science. We achieved this goal successfully. Visitors wrote that they were attracted to the exhibit because it was, “real bench science (not that much in science museums – hands-on stuff at Exploratorium are more to illustrate concepts, not do science).”  Another wrote: “It was the only thing like it in the museum.” Having a performance aspect to the exhibit was also a major attraction for many visitors, who commented on the importance of having a “live host”. The aestheticization and sensualization of the apparatus was also an important component of the success. In response to the question, “What attracted you to the exhibit”, many visitors to the exhibit responded with comments such as, “the sparks”; “ the electrical strikes: awesome!”; “the sound”; “the glass”; “interesting visually”; “looked very cool”.  Overall, 49% of those surveyed reported that they would like to see more exhibits featuring “live” experimentation. Moreover, 26% of those surveyed were repeat visitors to the exhibit. Clearly the idea that an exhibit can change or yield new and different results from one time to another is sufficient attraction for many visitors to revisit a venue.
